title: Virtual reality start-up 8i scores big name $US13.5 million funding
text:
Serial entrepreneur and 8i founder Linc Gasking Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Rose Powell A New Zealand-based virtual reality entertainment start-up has raised $US13.5 million ($18.4 million) from leading US venture funds and movie star Ashton Kutcher, as part of an accelerating trend of US funds seeking out deals in the Asia-Pacific region.
Serial entrepreneur Linc Gasking co-founded 8i, which develops software that can be used by virtual reality headsets such as Oculus Rift and PlayStation VR.
"We know the internet will be three-dimensional pretty soon, quicker than anyone imagined," Mr Gasking told Fairfax Media. "The raise gives us a global group of investors but also strategic investors to help make the connections we need."
These investors include RRE Ventures, Founders Fund, Samsung Ventures, Dolby Family Ventures, the Elisabeth Murdoch-run Freelands fund and movie star Ashton Kutcher.
Linc Gasking described the advent of virtual reality as a revolutionary change. Similar to the early gaming consoles, virtual reality is an emerging and expensive industry to thrive in. It burst into the broader public consciousness in late 2014, when Facebook acquired the leading virtual reality headset company, Oculus Rift, for a whopping $2 billion.
Virtual reality revolution Rather than create a competing hardware product, 8i is focusing on developing the software that produces the experiences viewed on the headsets or screens.
"There has been a lot of talk all through the media, radio, television and film about what is the next step in the evolution of media," Mr Gasking said.
Ashton Kutcher has backed the funding round describing it as an entirely new entertainment medium. Michael Clayton-Jones "But virtual reality isn't a step, it's a complete revolution beyond the two-dimensional screen."
Virtual reality software allows people to don a headset or use a screen and move through their environment, directly controlling where they look and how they move rather than taking in the point-of-view defined a the director.
Founders Fund partner Scott Nolan, who will join the board, told the Financial Times they were searching for the next breakthrough technology when they met the 8i team.
Expansion plans Congrats to @8iReality on closing this round of funding. Get ready for an entirely new entertainment medium
â€” ashton kutcher (@aplusk) October 14, 2015 The funding will allow the young company to continue to grow. It already straddles two headquarters: an engineering hub in Wellington New Zealand that builds and manages the digital platform as well as a sales office in San Francisco.
The $US13.5 million raised will go towards developing both teams but also launching a studio in Los Angeles' Culver City near Hollywood that works with music, film and entertainment producers to create the content to be explored on the platform.
"The biggest challenge for us is now harder than ever: narrowing down which opportunities to do in what order," Mr Gasking said.
"Everyone wants to do this. Once someone puts one of the headsets on, you know how huge and different the future is and a long list of stuff to [do] with it just unrolls in your head. Now with the funding, the struggle to narrow down our focus to what we can do in a timely way is even tougher."
Also tough will be the competition. Most major movie studios and development houses have their own divisions working on similar projects or have backed fledgling companies similar to 8i.
But Mr Gasking is confident 8i will survive the early heats to emerge as a leader in the field.
"We're staying rigorously focused on enabling the best videos, the highest quality experience we can, because that's ultimately what will win the day."
Correction: An earlier version of this story described Lord of the Rings director Peter Jackson as being involved in the company. He is not.
